intro: Alkanna amana, commonly known as the red sandalwood or alkanna, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the family Fabaceae, characterized by its compound leaves and pod-like fruits. The plant produces vibrant orange to red flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its roots contain a red dye used historically by indigenous peoples for body paint and textiles. Alkanna amana thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to drought conditions.
